Thank you to all the people who made #DebConf21 possible! The DebConf organisation team, Debian Video Team, our speakers, volunteers, and attendees. Would you like to join for organising the next DebConf? If so visit https://wiki.debian.org/DebConf/22 and contact the DebConf team.

#DebConf21 will shortly be over, so we shall console ourselves with (notional) cheese and wine. Bring your own cheese, weâ€™ll provide the company for the Closing Ceremony and Cheese and Wine party! https://debconf21.debconf.org/schedule/venue/1/
micronews.debian.org
#DebConf21 pauses for a break from 18:45 UTC through 20:00 UTC: it's just time to prepare cheese platter, to take out beverages from the fridge, and to open wine bottles. Don't miss the Cheese and Wine party online later! Other option is to follow the Poetry Event that is happening during the break, in channel two https://debconf21.debconf.org/schedule/venue/2/
micronews.debian.org
"src:developers-reference wants your help\!" The Debian developers-reference handbook (also available at www.debian.org/doc/manuals/developers-reference/ ) is still the main reference for developers although many areas have become somewhat outdatedâ€¦ If you are looking for ways to improve Debian by writing and improving documentation and or translating it, this talk is for you on channel one at 18:00 UTC, https://debconf21.debconf.org/schedule/venue/1/
micronews.debian.org
At 17:00 UTC, Debian Outreach will showcase the projects on which interns are currently working under Outreachy 2021 and also under Google Summer of Code 2021 (18:00). They will share their experience working with Debian. Follow the live streaming on channel two, https://debconf21.debconf.org/schedule/venue/2/
micronews.debian.org
autopkgtest, a test automation tool for Debian packages, is a central part of the contemporary Debian release process and quality control efforts. The activity "autopkgtest office hours" (17:00 UTC) aim to help fellow maintainers with their questions about implementing or improving autopkgtest support for their packages, https://debconf21.debconf.org/schedule/venue/1/

2021-08-15

For bullseye, the security suite is now named bullseye-security so users should adapt their APT source-list files and configuration accordingly when upgrading. More details on https://www.debian.org/releases/bullseye/amd64/release-notes/ch-information.en.html#security-archive #NewInBullseye #Debian11Bullseye
micronews.debian.org
Debian Edu / Skolelinux Bullseye â€” a complete Linux solution for your school https://www.debian.org/News/2021/20210815
micronews.debian.org
Bits from the Release Team: say hello to our studious bookworm https://lists.debian.org/debian-devel-announce/2021/08/msg00001.html
micronews.debian.org
If your APT configuration also involves pinning or APT::Default-Release, it is likely to require adjustments as the codename of the security archive no longer matches that of the regular archive. More details and examples in https://www.debian.org/releases/bullseye/amd64/release-notes/ch-information.en.html#security-archive #NewInDebianBullseye #ReleasingDebianBullseye
micronews.debian.org

2021-08-14

The release notes for Debian bullseye are available in 17 languages: https://www.debian.org/releases/bullseye/releasenotes #ReleasingDebianBullseye
micronews.debian.org
Many ARM architecture devices use "Mali" GPUs. Debian 11 now supports them with the free software Panfrost and Lima drivers https://wiki.debian.org/PanfrostLima #NewInDebianBullseye #ReleasingDebianBullseye
micronews.debian.org
Regexp matching support is now compiled into journalctl so that it is always available in Debian 11 #NewInDebianBullseye #ReleasingDebianBullseye
micronews.debian.org
win32-loader, which enables Debian installation from Windows without use of separate installation media, now supports UEFI and Secure Boot #NewInDebianBullseye #ReleasingDebianBullseye
micronews.debian.org
The official press announcement for Debian bullseye is available https://www.debian.org/News/2021/20210814 #ReleasingDebianBullseye
micronews.debian.org
Debian 11 bullseye has been released! https://bits.debian.org/2021/08/bullseye-released.html
micronews.debian.org
For bullseye, the security suite is now named bullseye-security so users should adapt their APT source-list files and configuration accordingly when upgrading. More details on https://www.debian.org/releases/bullseye/amd64/release-notes/ch-information.en.html#security-archive
micronews.debian.org
If your system is Debian 9 (stretch) or older, please follow the instructions in the Release Notes for Debian 10 to upgrade to Debian 10 (buster) first https://www.debian.org/releases/buster/releasenotes and then, you can upgrade to Debian 11 bullseye #ReleasingDebianBullseye
micronews.debian.org
Debian 11 is now cascading to a mirror near you! If you can't wait any longer, the CD images are now available from https://cdimage.debian.org/debian-cd/current/ #ReleasingDebianBullseye
micronews.debian.org
CD images have been signed off - the release can continue #ReleasingDebianBullseye
micronews.debian.org
The manual pages for several projects in a number of languages, including French, Spanish, and Macedonian, have been substantially improved. To benefit from this, please install manpages-xx package (where xx is the code for your preferred natural language) #NewInDebianBullseye #ReleasingDebianBullseye
micronews.debian.org
The final image test is almost complete! #ReleasingDebianBullseye
micronews.debian.org
There are 1,152,960,944 lines of code in Debian bullseye. #ReleasingDebianBullseye
micronews.debian.org
More than 6,208 people have contributed to Debian. Some of the contributors are shown in https://contributors.debian.org/contributors/flat #ReleasingDebianBullseye
micronews.debian.org
CD testing is nearing completion! The test matrix is quite extensive and most tests require real hardware so this is the most time-consuming part of the release process #ReleasingDebianBullseye
micronews.debian.org
There are 645 tags in the Debtags vocabulary, with 102370 known packages to tag. Of these, 18093 were tagged by humans and 84277 were tagged by robots. #ReleasingDebianBullseye
micronews.debian.org
CD testing is a great way to contribute to the release and get stuck into Debian. liz in Brisbane, AU has just filed her first ever bug report testing a live image! https://wiki.debian.org/Teams/DebianCd #ReleasingDebianBullseye
micronews.debian.org
Releasing Debian 11 doesn't mean Debian 10 "buster" is abandoned. Debian supports the previous version for at least twelve months following a new release, before it moves to the LTS and eLTS teams for further maintenance #ReleasingDebianBullseye
micronews.debian.org
All images have now generated and the builder is cooling back down! Testing continues before they are released to the mirrors #ReleasingDebianBullseye
micronews.debian.org
There are 31,387 source packages in Debian bullseye. #ReleasingDebianBullseye
micronews.debian.org
bullseye is the first Debian release providing a Linux kernel which has support for the exFAT filesystem, and defaults to using it for mounting exFAT filesystems #NewInDebianBullseye #ReleasingDebianBullseye
micronews.debian.org
So far, there are no show-stopping bugs revealed by CD testing so everything looks good for a smooth release #ReleasingDebianBullseye
micronews.debian.org
The scanner on your combined printer/scanner device can also be accessed with driverless scanning, thanks to the new "sane-airscan" package. Try it today! #NewInDebianBullseye #ReleasingDebianBullseye
micronews.debian.org
The systemd persistent journal is active in Debian 11 by default. It doesn't replace or conflict with traditional logging daemons such as rsyslog, but it can replace them if you wish #NewInDebianBullseye #ReleasingDebianBullseye
micronews.debian.org
The Debian 11 bullseye desktop theme is Homeworld https://wiki.debian.org/DebianArt/Themes/Homeworld by Juliette Taka. Over 19 different themes were proposed. #ReleasingDebianBullseye
micronews.debian.org
The first test images are arriving from the CD team and will be thoroughly tested by our army of helpers over the next few hours #ReleasingDebianBullseye
micronews.debian.org
Say hello to bookworm: FTPMasters have created the next testing distribution, codename bookworm, as a copy of bullseye. It will get its first updates from the unstable suite in a few days time when the release cycle begins all over again #ReleasingDebianBullseye
micronews.debian.org
Debian 11 uses the new "yescrypt" password hashing format by default. For more information about it see "man 5 crypt" #NewInDebianBullseye #ReleasingDebianBullseye
micronews.debian.org
Looking for the program to open a particular file? The new "open" command will try and do the right thing for you automatically! #NewInDebianBullseye #ReleasingDebianBullseye
micronews.debian.org
Debian's CD team is warming up their build server - did you know it uses 88 CPUs, 377GiB of RAM and over 8TiB of SSDs to generate images for bullseye's 9 architectures? #ReleasingDebianBullseye
micronews.debian.org
The Stable Release Managers have approved bullseye as Debian 11 and accepted it onto their support. The release files are signed and back with FTP masters! #ReleasingDebianBullseye
micronews.debian.org
Debian 11 extends driverless printing to USB devices with the new "ipp-usb" package #NewInDebianBullseye #ReleasingDebianBullseye
micronews.debian.org
We highly recommend you read the Release Notes before installing or upgrading to Debian 11. They are written, reviewed and updated with care, catering for both new and experienced users, and will help ease your installations and prevent issues when upgrading your systems https://www.debian.org/releases/bullseye/releasenotes #ReleasingDebianBullseye
micronews.debian.org
Release Managers are checking that everything about bullseye is in tip-top condition and ready for publication #ReleasingDebianBullseye
micronews.debian.org
Next the database changes are being made so that dak, the Debian Archive Kit, will understand the new meaning of "stable" and "oldstable" #ReleasingDebianBullseye
micronews.debian.org
The Debian publicity team will do a live coverage of the #ReleasingDebianBullseye process, follow us via Debian Micronews or your favorite social network! https://micronews.debian.org
micronews.debian.org
The bullseye version of the Debian Installer is being moved into its new home. The installer has a long history, you can read some of it at https://salsa.debian.org/installer-team/debian-installer/-/blob/master/doc/history.txt #ReleasingDebianBullseye
micronews.debian.org
FTP-masters have moved "buster" to the oldstable alias in preparation for promoting testing to "bullseye" #ReleasingDebianBullseye

Today (last Friday of July) is the System Administrator Appreciation Day. Don't forget your backups, and show your appreciation to your local #sysadmin :-) If you want to know more about DSA, the Debian System Administrator team, you can have a look at their webpage https://dsa.debian.org/ - Thanks DSA for taking care of the Debian infrastructure!

2021-06-15

The Debian Project hosts all its development IRC channels on irc.oftc.net and also has a thriving community on irc.libera.chat. The Debian Project no longer has control of #debian on the freenode IRC network. We thank the former freenode staff for their tireless work over many years. Please read https://wiki.debian.org/IRC for more information about Debian IRC channels.
micronews.debian.org

2020-08-30

DebConf20 online closes. We hope you enjoyed our conference and coverage of The Universal Operating System and the many hands that bring it to you. https://bits.debian.org/2020/08/debconf20-closes.html
micronews.debian.org
Many of the streamed sessions from #DebConf20 are already uploaded in https://meetings-archive.debian.net/pub/debian-meetings/2020/DebConf20/ and the remaining ones will appear in the following days. Thank you again from all of us at Debian!
micronews.debian.org
Did you attend #DebConf20 and want to share your experience about it? We appreciate feedback about what worked well and the things we could improve, please send your comments to feedback at _debconf_dot_ org.
micronews.debian.org
Thank you to all the people who made #DebConf20 possible! The DebConf organisation team, Debian Video Team, our speakers, volunteers, and attendees. Would you like to join for organising the next DebConf? If so visit https://wiki.debian.org/DebConf/21 and contact the DebConf team.
micronews.debian.org
DebConf20 online closes

micronews.debian.org
We take a break for this moment and will return to #DebConf20 at 22:00 UTC.

2019-07-07

"Debian Buster Release" by Andy Simpkins https://blog.koipond.org.uk/archives/138 #releasingDebianBuster
micronews.debian.org
Debian Edu / Skolelinux Buster â€” a complete Linux solution for your school https://www.debian.org/News/2019/20190707
micronews.debian.org
Debian GNU/Hurd 2019 released! https://www.debian.org/ports/hurd/hurd-news
micronews.debian.org
If you use apt-get to upgrade to buster, you won't be asked about the security repository info changed from 'testing' to 'stable'. Use the --allow-releaseinfo-change option, as Eriberto Mota explains here: http://eriberto.pro.br/blog/2019/07/07/debian-repository-changed-its-suite-value-from-testing-to-stable/ or use apt instead
micronews.debian.org
Trying to upgrade to buster? Do you get this error 'N: This must be accepted explicitly before updates for this repository can be applied'? See https://bugs.debian.org/929248
micronews.debian.org
Bits from the Release Team: ride like the wind, Bullseye! https://lists.debian.org/debian-devel-announce/2019/07/msg00002.html
micronews.debian.org
Debian 10 buster has been released! https://bits.debian.org/2019/07/buster-released.html
micronews.debian.org
The official press announcement for Debian buster's release is now available https://www.debian.org/News/2019/20190706 #releasingDebianBuster
micronews.debian.org
Debian stretch is not forgotten in the excitement - it will receive a further 12 months support from the Debian Security Team, and then they will hand over to the LTS and ELTS teams #releasingDebianBuster
micronews.debian.org
Buster's release has been noticed by the CD distribution network https://www.acc.umu.se/technical/statistics/ftp/monitordata/ #releasingDebianBuster
micronews.debian.org
Debian 10 "buster" has been released!

2019-07-06

The Debian website is being updated to list buster as stable and link to the new images for downloading #releasingDebianBuster

Debian FTP masters are now pushing the results of today's work to the mirror network #releasingDebianBuster
micronews.debian.org
Final image test results are being collated and the Debian CD team are preparing to sign them off - buster is very nearly with us! #releasingDebianBuster
micronews.debian.org
There are 645 tags in the Debtags vocabulary, and 95661 known packages to tag. Of these, 17050 are tagged by humans, and 78611 are tagged by robots. https://debtags.debian.org/reports/stats/ #ReleasingDebianBuster
micronews.debian.org
Used for Debian events, booths, or as a banner of pride, Debian Flyers are available in 9 languages. You can help improve or translate it into other languages. https://debian.pages.debian.net/debian-flyers/ #ReleasingDebianBuster
micronews.debian.org
Debian 10 buster has AppArmor enabled per default. https://wiki.debian.org/AppArmor/HowToUse #ReleasingDebianBuster
micronews.debian.org
Officially supported architectures for Debian 10: 32-bit PC (i386) and 64-bit PC (amd64), 64-bit ARM (arm64), ARM EABI (armel), ARMv7 (EABI hard-float ABI, armhf), MIPS (mips (big-endian) and mipsel (little-endian)), 64-bit little-endian MIPS (mips64el), 64-bit little-endian PowerPC (ppc64el), IBM System z (s390x).
micronews.debian.org
The Debian security team has issued at least 4475 advisories over its lifetime. https://www.debian.org/security/ #ReleasingDebianBuster
micronews.debian.org
Following Pixar's Toy Story naming scheme, Debian's releases have been: buzz, rex, bo, hamm, slink, potato, woody, sarge, etch, lenny, squeeze, wheezy, jessie, stretch and now buster. Future releases will be bullseye and then bookworm.
micronews.debian.org
There are at least 91 different Debian derivatives known and active to the derivatives census. https://wiki.debian.org/Derivatives/Census #ReleasingDebianBuster
micronews.debian.org
In addition of the officially supported architectures, the Debian Ports Team maintains other architectures. See more info in https://www.ports.debian.org/
micronews.debian.org
With more than 300 packages in the Debian Astro Pure Blend, Debian buster is well prepared to solve current and upcoming astronomical and astrophysical problems https://blends.debian.org/astro/ #ReleasingDebianBuster
micronews.debian.org
Testing of the live images is nearing completion! #releasingDebianBuster
micronews.debian.org
You don't need to be an expert to contribute to Debian! Assisting users with problems on the user support channels is a large contribution to Debian. https://www.debian.org/support #ReleasingDebianBuster
micronews.debian.org
There are 34 vendors of Debian DVDs and USB sticks in 18 countries. Become a vendor today! https://www.debian.org/CD/vendors/ #ReleasingDebianBuster
micronews.debian.org
Debian Volunteers Daisy and George work diliigently toward the release. https://www.jwiltshire.org.uk/2019/07/06/daisy-and-george-help-debian/ #ReleaseDebianBuster
micronews.debian.org
GNOME in Debian 10 buster has changed its default display server from Xorg to Wayland. https://wiki.debian.org/Wayland #ReleasingDebianBuster
micronews.debian.org
Debian 10 buster has 28,939 source packages with 11,610,055 source files. See more stats (languages, other) at https://sources.debian.org/stats/buster/ #ReleasingDebianBuster
micronews.debian.org
There have been about 31 different official and unofficial ports to various kernels and hardware types https://www.debian.org/ports/ #ReleasingDebianBuster
micronews.debian.org
Debian buster is the first release with a debian-policy mandating 'packages should be reproducible' (since policy 4.1.0) #ReleasingDebianBuster
micronews.debian.org
Meanwhile the tests are ongoing, the Debian website is being prepared to offer all the info about Debian buster released as stable #releasingDebianBuster

micronews.debian.org

micronews.debian.org
a keyring update for adding key ID EF0F382A1A7B6500 is coming soon #releasingstretch
micronews.debian.org
if you get the message: W: There is no public key available for the following key IDs EF0F382A1A7B6500 you can proceed with the upgrade #releasingstretch
micronews.debian.org
To celebrate the stretch release, we have more than 45 parties in 25 different countries as well as the Debian party line https://wiki.debian.org/ReleasePartyStretch #releasingstretch
micronews.debian.org
When upgrading from Jessie to Stretch, it can be a good idea to purge old packages before the first reboot. #releasingstretch
micronews.debian.org
Be sure to check out the upgrading advice for troubleshooting and warnings prior to your upgrade. https://www.debian.org/releases/stretch/amd64/release-notes/ch-upgrading.en.html #releasingstretch
micronews.debian.org
Be aware that any non-Debian packages on your system may be removed during the upgrade because of conflicting dependencies. #releasingstretch
micronews.debian.org
Before upgrading your system, it is strongly recommended that you make a full backup of information you can't afford to lose #releasingstretch
